# HCOMP 2024: Call for Papers

The Twelfth AAAI Conference on Human Computation and Crowdsourcing (HCOMP 2024) will be held **October 16–19, 2024**, in **Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania**. The conference theme is **''Responsible Crowd Work for Better AI.''**

HCOMP is the premier venue for disseminating the latest research findings on human computation and crowdsourcing, promoting interdisciplinary research across AI, HCI, economics, social computing, digital humanities, policy, and ethics.

HCOMP 2024 is colocated with ACM UIST 2024 (October 13-16, 2024).

# HIPS 2025: Call for Papers

The 30th International Workshop on High-Level Parallel Programming Models and Supportive Environments (HIPS), held in conjunction with IPDPS 2025, will take place on **June 3, 2025**, in **Milan, Lombardy, Italy**.

## Overview

The workshop focuses on high-level programming of multiprocessors, compute clusters, and massively parallel machines. It serves as a forum for research in parallel applications, language design, compilers, runtime systems, and programming tools, presenting the latest ideas and findings in these rapidly changing fields.

This year, we especially invite papers demonstrating innovative approaches in:

*   Emerging programming models for large-scale parallel systems and many-core architectures.
*   Programming models and environments for the Edge-Cloud-HPC Continuum.
*   Application of recent AI technologies in high-level programming models.

## Topics of Interest

Topics of interest to the HIPS workshop include but are not limited to:

*   High-level and domain-specific programming systems
*   Language/compiler support for AI/ML and Cybersecurity/Privacy (e.g., ML-based auto-tuning)
*   Application of Large Language Models in high-level programming environments
*   Higher-level programming support for quantum computing/quantum simulation
*   Programming Models and Tools for the Edge-Cloud-HPC Continuum
*   Task-based programming systems
*   (Scalable) programming tools and tools for power & performance analysis, modeling, monitoring and debugging, and core correctness
*   Compiler analysis and optimization techniques
*   OS and architectural support for parallel programming and debugging
*   Software and system support for extreme scalability including fault tolerance and power-aware HPC
*   Programming environments for heterogeneous multicore systems and accelerators such as GPUs and FPGAs
*   Solutions for programming paradigms for GPUs from different hardware vendors
*   Dynamism in applications and system resources
*   Performance portability
*   Efforts for improving the sustainability of scientific software
*   Languages and runtime support for multi-science/coupled codes, including but not limited to ensemble computing and uncertainty quantification
*   New programming languages and constructs for exploiting parallelism and locality

## Important Deadlines

*   **Submission due date:** January 27, 2025 (extended), Anywhere on Earth (AoE)
*   **Author notification:** February 21, 2025 AoE
*   **Camera-ready papers:** March 13, 2025 AoE

## Submission Guidelines

Authors are invited to submit original papers in two separate tracks:

*   **Full papers:** May not exceed 10 single-spaced double-column pages using 10-point size font on 8.5x11 inch pages (IEEE conference style), including figures, tables, and references. Accepted full papers will have the opportunity to present their work during the workshop.
*   **Short papers:** May not exceed 4 single-spaced double-column pages using 10-point size font on 8.5x11 inch pages (IEEE conference style), including figures, tables, and references. Accepted short papers will have the opportunity to give a short presentation during the workshop.

All submissions should be formatted according to the IPDPS paper style (IEEE conference style, single-blind).

**Submit papers through the IPDPS-HIPS Linklings site:** [https://ssl.linklings.net/conferences/ipdps/?page=Submit&id=HIPSWorkshopFullSubmission&site=ipdps2025](https://ssl.linklings.net/conferences/ipdps/?page=Submit&id=HIPSWorkshopFullSubmission&site=ipdps2025)

## Proceedings

The accepted full papers will be published in the IPDPS 2025 Workshops proceedings by the IEEE Xplore Digital Library. Short papers will not appear in the proceedings.

**Note:** Presentation of an accepted paper at the conference is a requirement of publication. Any paper that is not presented at the conference will not be included in IEEE Xplore.

## Registration

Attendance at this workshop is part of the registration for IPDPS 2025. Register [here](http://www.ipdps.org/ipdps2025/2025-registration.html).

**Note:** At least one author of each paper must be registered for the symposium by March 31st in order for the paper to be published in the proceedings. It must be a full registration unless the sole author of the paper is a student.

# HCW 2025: Call for Papers

The thirty-fourth Heterogeneity in Computing Workshop (HCW) will be held on **June 4, 2025**, at the **Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy**. HCW is organized annually in conjunction with the **39th IEEE International Parallel and Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS 2025)**.

HCW serves as a venue to discuss and innovate in all theoretical and practical aspects of heterogeneous computing, including design, programmability, efficient utilization, algorithms, modeling, and applications. Most modern computing systems are heterogeneous, requiring management and exploitation of their diverse components.

## Topics

Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   **Heterogeneous multicore systems and architectures:** Design, exploration, and experimental analysis of systems like GPUs, AI chips, FPGAs, big.LITTLE, and application-specific architectures.
*   **Heterogeneous parallel and distributed systems:** Design and analysis of computing grids, cloud systems, hybrid clusters, datacenters, geo-distributed computing systems, and supercomputers.
*   **Deep memory hierarchies:** Design and analysis of memory hierarchies including SRAM, DRAM, Flash/SSD, HDD, NUMA architectures, cache coherence strategies, and novel memory systems.
*   **On-chip, off-chip, and heterogeneous network architectures:** Network-on-chip (NoC) architectures and protocols, off-chip (chip-to-chip) network architectures, heterogeneous networks, and large-scale parallel and distributed heterogeneous network design.
*   **Programming models and tools:** Programming paradigms, middleware, runtime systems, performance-abstraction tradeoffs, and interoperability for heterogeneous systems.
*   **Resource management and algorithms for heterogeneous systems:** Parallel algorithms, scheduling strategies for multicore architectures, and resource management for large-scale heterogeneous systems.
*   **Modeling, characterization, and optimizations:** Performance models, time-to-solve optimizations, electricity consumption modeling, failure management modeling, and security modeling for heterogeneous platforms.
*   **Applications on heterogeneous systems:** Case studies, Big Data systems, data-intensive computing, and scientific computing.

### Hot Topics (Especially Invited)

*   **Heterogeneous Integration of Quantum Computing:** Architectures and software frameworks for classical and quantum computing integration.
*   **Heterogeneity and Interoperability in Software & Data Systems:** Architectures and frameworks for interoperability in software and data systems.
*   **Heterogeneous Computing for Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL):** Accelerators and software frameworks for ML/DL on heterogeneous systems.
*   **Closing the loop on the design of heterogeneous compilers, runtimes, and hardware:** Advancements in machine understanding of code for holistic compiler, runtime, and hardware design.

## Important Dates

*   **Paper submission:** February 9, 2025

*   **Submission Site:** Files should be submitted via the [IPDPS 2025 submission site](https://ssl.linklings.net/conferences/ipdps).

# HLPP 2025: Call for Papers

The **18th International Symposium on High-level Parallel Programming and Applications (HLPP 2025)** will be held as a two-day event, hosted by the Computer Science Department of the University of Innsbruck in Austria, from **July 3-4, 2025**.

HLPP focuses on high-level parallel programming of multi-/many-core platforms, accelerator architectures, heterogeneous compute clusters, and highly parallel or distributed infrastructures. It serves as a forum for researchers and engineers in parallel computing, offering an excellent opportunity to present latest ideas and findings. The symposium especially encourages innovative approaches in parallel programming models and applications, high-level parallel languages, compilers, runtime systems, and programming tools for all classes of parallel machines.

HLPP 2025 aims to deliver an enriching conference experience, featuring impactful research, constructive discussions, and valuable networking opportunities.

## Keynote Speakers

*   **Prof. Dr. Gabriele Keller** from Utrecht University, Netherlands
*   **Prof. Dr. Martin Schulz** from the Technical University of Munich, Germany

*   **Formatting:** Papers should adhere to the [Springer-Nature journal format](https://www.springernature.com/gp/authors/campaigns/latex-author-support#c17590862).
*   **Review Process:** Each paper will be peer-reviewed by at least three reviewers using a **single-blind review** process.
*   **Submission System:** Submissions are handled via EasyChair: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=hlpp2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=hlpp2025)

Registration for HLPP 2025 is now open. You can register [here](/hlpp-2025/registration).

# Call for Papers

The Twenty-sixth International Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile 2025)

Sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE

**Dates:** February 26-27, 2025
**Location:** Palm Springs, CA

## Workshop Focus

HotMobile 2025 continues the series of highly selective, interactive workshops focused on mobile applications, systems, and environments, as well as their underlying state-of-the-art technologies. Its small workshop format makes it ideal for presenting and discussing new directions or controversial approaches.

## Solicited Submissions

We solicit submissions of papers that focus primarily on systems and applications and propose new directions of research, advocate non-traditional approaches, or generate controversy and discussion. We encourage early work and papers likely to stimulate reflection and discussion.

Additionally, HotMobile seeks proposals for posters and live demonstrations describing novel work on mobile systems, applications, and services. Posters are suited for controversial work or promising new ideas, while live demos showcase feasibility and usefulness.

## Topics of Interest

We take a broad view of Mobile Systems research, including:

*   Novel applications, environments, and devices supporting mobility.
*   Operating system and distributed system support for mobile computing.
*   Wearable computing, internet of things, edge computing, sensing, and context-awareness.
*   HCI issues related to mobile computing.
*   Security and privacy of mobile computing.
*   Management, configuration, and deployment of systems supporting mobility.
*   Wireless technology, as it pertains to mobile systems and applications.
*   Social issues related to mobile computing.
*   System and application support for the use of ML and AI on mobile platforms.

## Important Dates

*   **Paper submission (original deadline):** ~~October 11, 2024~~ 
*   **Poster/Demo submission (extended):** January 20, 2025
*   **Notification of acceptance (Posters/Demos):** January 22, 2025
*   **Camera-ready deadline (Posters/Demos):** January 24, 2025
*   **Workshop Dates:** February 26-27, 2025

## Submission Guidelines

### For Papers

*   **Length:** Submissions should contain 6 or fewer U.S. letter pages, including all references, figures, and tables.
*   **Anonymity:** Submissions should **not** be anonymous.
*   **Formatting:**
    *   Font size no smaller than 10pt.
    *   Font size of the bibliography no smaller than 9pt.
    *   Double column format with each column having dimensions 9.25 inches x 3.33 inches, a space of 0.33 inches between the two columns, and with no more than 55 lines of text per column.
    *   Fit properly on US letter-sized paper (8.5 inches x 11 inches).
*   **Template:** We recommend the use of the "sigconf" ACM proceedings template, available at: [http://www.acm.org/](http://www.acm.org/).
*   **Submission Site:** [https://hotmobile2025.hotcrp.com/](https://hotmobile2025.hotcrp.com/) (Account creation required).
*   **Confidentiality:** Submissions will be handled as confidential material during the review.
*   **Originality:** Papers must not have been published elsewhere and may not be simultaneously under submission at another venue. Papers accompanied by nondisclosure agreement forms are not acceptable.
*   **Publication:** Accepted papers will be publicly available from the workshop's website for a limited time.

### For Posters and Demos

*   **Abstract Length:** Submissions must include an extended abstract no longer than one 8.5x11-inch page, including all figures and references.
*   **Submission Site:** [https://hotmobile25-posterdemo.hotcrp.com/](https://hotmobile25-posterdemo.hotcrp.com/)
*   **Formatting:**
    *   US letter size (8.5x11 inches).
    *   Two columns, using 10-pt font size for the text body, with at least one-inch margin on all sides.
    *   Submissions must be in Adobe PDF format.
*   **Content:** Include the title of the poster/demo and the author list, including affiliations in both the PDF file and in the body of the email. Prefix your title with “Poster:” for a poster submission and “Demo:” for a demo submission. Please do not anonymize your submissions.
*   **Final Version:** Accepted posters and demos will need to submit a one-page version using 9-pt font size.
*   **Demo Video:** For demo submissions, an optional companion video (no more than one minute) is encouraged, highlighting technical contributions. Include the YouTube URL in the extended abstract.
*   **Publication:** Accepted posters and demos will be published in the proceedings.
*   **Award:** This year's poster/demo session will feature a Best Poster/Demo award.

**Note:** Presenting at HotMobile is a good way to get early feedback on research ideas. A full-length paper on the same topic submitted to a conference in less than a year is unlikely to include sufficient new material.

# HotNets 2025: Call for Papers

The 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks (HotNets 2025) will bring together researchers to engage in a lively debate on the theory and practice of computer networking and networked systems. HotNets provides a venue to discuss innovative ideas and debate future research agendas for the field.

## Overview

We invite researchers and practitioners to submit short position papers. We encourage submissions that identify fundamental open questions, advocate for new approaches, offer constructive critiques of the state of networking research, re-frame or debunk existing work, report unexpected early results from a deployment, report promising but unproven ideas, or propose new evaluation methods. Authors need not support their ideas with full evaluations; well-reasoned arguments or preliminary evaluations are sufficient support for the possibility of the paper's claims in HotNets.

We seek interesting ideas over incremental, well-baked systems. An ideal submission has the potential to open a line of inquiry for the networking and adjacent communities. We strongly discourage "conference papers in the miniature." The program committee will explicitly favor early work and papers likely to stimulate reflection and discussion, ideally benefiting the networking community broadly, over incremental work that is ready for publication at a conference.

HotNets takes a broad view of networking research. The scope includes (but is not limited to) new ideas that relate to mobile, wide-area, data-center, home, and enterprise networks and that use a variety of link technologies (e.g. wired, wireless, optical, visual, and acoustic), as well as social networks and network architecture. HotNets encompasses all aspects of networks, which include (but is not limited to) packet-processing and transmission hardware and software, virtualization, mobility, provisioning and resource management, performance, energy consumption, sustainability, topology, robustness, measurement, diagnosis, verification, privacy, security, economics and evolution, theory, usability, machine learning, and interactions with applications.

This year, the program committee will do an initial fast round of reviewing that will provide early rejection or advancement to later rounds of more traditional, thorough reviewing. The program committee will select papers based on originality, likelihood to stimulate insightful discussion, and technical merit. Accepted papers will be posted online prior to the workshop and will be published in the ACM Digital Library to facilitate wide dissemination of the ideas discussed at the workshop.

## Important Dates

*   **Paper submission deadline:** July 9, 2025 (23:59 AoE)
*   **Author notification:** September 19, 2025

## Submission and Formatting

*   Papers should be formatted according to the **two-column ACM proceedings format**.
*   Each paper should have no more than **6 pages**, excluding references, in **10 point font**. There is no limit on the page count for references, however appendices are not allowed.
*   Papers must contain novel ideas and must differ significantly in content from previously published papers.
*   All submissions must be **blind**: they must not indicate the names or affiliations of the authors in the paper.
*   Only electronic submissions in **PDF** will be accepted.
*   Submissions must be written in English, render without error using standard tools (e.g., Acrobat Reader), and print on US Letter paper.
*   Each reference must list all authors of the paper (i.e., do not use "et al."). The citations should be in numeric style, e.g., [52].
*   Please ensure that figures and tables are legible, even after the paper is printed in gray-scale.
*   Papers that exceed the length requirement or deviate from the expected format will be rejected.

A LaTeX class file that follows the prescribed submission format is available: [hotnets25-template.zip](https://hotnets.acm.org/2025/docs/hotnets25-template.zip)

For the LaTeX template, the first two lines should be:
```latex
\documentclass[sigconf, 10pt, anonymous, nonacm]{acmart}
       \settopmatter{printfolios=true, printccs=false, printacmref=false}
```

Submit papers on the [HotCRP](https://hotnets25.hotcrp.com/).

## Policies

### Policy on Concurrent Submissions

Concurrent submissions to HotNets 2025 and any other peer-reviewed venue that cover the same work (differences in the degree of detail given the two venues' length limits notwithstanding) are prohibited, and will result in the immediate rejection of the HotNets submission in question. "Concurrent" means any other peer-reviewed venue whose reviewing period (i.e., between submission and notification) overlaps with that of HotNets. The "same work" means, for example, a submission overlapping significantly in content with a conference submission. However, a position paper submitted to HotNets (e.g., that reflects broadly on the state of some aspect of the field, adopts a position as to how the field should move forward, or articulates a broad avenue of future work) will not be considered the "same work" as a conference-length paper on a specific system that addresses a point under the broad umbrella covered by the position paper. Authors with questions about this policy should contact the PC co-chairs before submitting.

### Ethical Concerns

As part of the submission process, authors must attest that their work complies with all applicable ethical standards of their home institution(s), including, but not limited to privacy policies and policies on experiments involving humans. Note that submitting research for approval by one's institution's ethics review body is necessary, but not sufficient – in cases where the PC has concerns about the ethics of the work in a submission, the PC will have its own discussion of the ethics of that work. The PC takes a broad view of what constitutes an ethical concern, and authors agree to be available at any time during the review process to rapidly respond to queries from the PC chairs regarding ethical standards.

## Workshop Participation

HotNets attendance is limited to roughly 90 people in person to facilitate a lively discussion (potentially with additional virtual participants). In-person invitations will be allocated first to one author of each paper, HotNets organizers and committee members, and conference sponsors. We require the paper presentations to be in-person (if authors have any concerns about this, they are welcome to contact the PC chairs). To promote an inclusive workshop, HotNets will also make a limited number of open registration slots for in-person attendance available to the community.

## Location

Stamp Student Union at University of Maryland
3972 Campus Dr, College Park, MD, USA 20742

[Directions to Stamp Student Union](https://maps.google.com/?q=Stamp+Student+Union+at+University+of+Maryland+3972+Campus+Dr+College+Park+MD+20742)

Remote Attendance: TBD.

## Event Information

HotNets 2025 will be an in-person event.

# Call for Papers and Discussions

The 20th Workshop on Hot Topics in Operating Systems (HotOS XX) solicits **position papers** proposing new directions of systems research, advocating innovative approaches to long-standing problems, or reporting on deep insights gained from experience with real-world systems. The program committee will explicitly favor papers likely to stimulate reflection and discussion. Early-stage work where authors can benefit from community feedback is highly encouraged.

HotOS takes a broad view of systems research, encompassing operating systems, storage, distributed systems, mobile and embedded systems, virtualization, programming languages, networking, security, dependability, and manageability. It also welcomes contributions influenced by fields such as hardware design, machine learning, verification, economics, social organization, and nontraditional computing systems.

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Research and Position Papers:**
    *   Length: No longer than **5 pages** including figures and tables, plus as many pages as needed for references.
    *   Formatting: Adhere to ACM's formatting conventions using the `acmart` style (`\documentclass[sigconf,10pt]{acmart}`). This includes 10-point font, two columns, 8.5x11-inch paper, 10-point Times Roman or Libertine font on 12-point leading, 0.75-inch margins, and a 0.33-inch gutter.
    *   Anonymity: Submissions must be **double blind**. Authors must make a good faith effort to anonymize their submissions, avoiding explicit or implicit self-identification in references or acknowledgments. Pages should be numbered. Figures and tables must be legible in black and white.
    *   Rejection: Submissions not meeting these criteria will be rejected without review; no deadline extensions will be granted for reformatting.
    *   ORCID ID: Authors must obtain an ORCID ID for the publishing process.

*   **Panel and Event Proposals:**
    *   Length: 1-page proposal (using the same format as papers) plus pages for references and supporting letters.
    *   Anonymity: Unlike papers, panel and event proposals need **not be anonymous** (i.e., they may be single blind).
    *   Evaluation: Proposals will be evaluated based on topic relevance and potential to engage the audience. Topics such as industry perspectives on systems research, diversity and inclusion, under-appreciated open source technologies, and hardware trends are encouraged.

## Key Dates

*   **Paper or Panel Proposal Submission Deadline:** **January 15, 2025** (AoE)
*   **Author Notifications:** April 1, 2025
*   **Camera-ready Deadline:** April 15, 2025
*   **Workshop Dates:** May 14–16, 2025

## Submission Method

Submissions must be in PDF format via the web submission form: [https://hotos25.hotcrp.com/](https://hotos25.hotcrp.com/). Select your submission type (paper or proposal) on the form.

## Attendance and Registration

HotOS will be an **in-person workshop**. At least one author of each accepted paper is expected to present and participate. Alternatives may be considered in extreme cases (e.g., visa issues) upon contacting the chairs.

Registration will be limited to encourage deeper discussion. At least two authors per accepted paper will receive invitations to attend if desired. A separate invitation request process will be announced for non-authors, including students and industry practitioners.

## Policy

*   **Simultaneous submission, previously published work, or plagiarism** constitutes dishonesty and is prohibited. Prior or concurrent publication in non-peer-reviewed contexts (like arXiv) is permitted, but the submission must use an anonymized project name.
*   Authors are subject to all ACM Publications Policies, including those on Research Involving Human Participants and Subjects.

# HPDC 2025: Call for Papers

## Overview

The ACM International Symposium on High-Performance Parallel and Distributed Computing (HPDC) is the premier annual conference for presenting the latest research on the design, implementation, evaluation, and use of parallel and distributed systems for high-end computing. The 34th HPDC will take place in **Notre Dame, Indiana, United States, July 20-23, 2025**.

## Scope and Topics

Submissions are welcomed on high-performance parallel and distributed computing (HPDC) topics including but not limited to: clouds, clusters, grids, big data, massively multicore, and extreme-scale computing systems. Experience reports of operational deployments that provide significantly novel insights for future research on HPDC applications and systems are also welcome.

In the context of high-performance parallel and distributed computing, the topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Datacenter, HPC, cloud, serverless, and edge/IoT computing platforms
*   Heterogeneous computing accelerators and non-volatile memory systems
*   File and storage systems, I/O, and data management
*   Operating systems and networks
*   System software and middleware for parallel and distributed systems
*   Programming languages and runtime systems
*   Big data stacks and big data ecosystems
*   Scientific applications, algorithms, and workflows
*   Resource management and scheduling
*   Performance modeling, benchmarking, and engineering
*   Fault tolerance, reliability, and availability
*   Operational guarantees, risk assessment, and management
*   Energy efficiency and sustainability
*   AI topics, which must relate to parallel and distributed computing systems
*   Novel post-Moore computing technologies including neuromorphic, brain-inspired computing, and quantum computing

HPDC welcomes submissions that utilize AI to enhance the above topics of interest or that utilize distributed systems to enhance AI frameworks, but it is highlighted that an HPDC submission must address and articulate its connection with parallel and distributed computing research.

## Important Dates (AoE)

*   **Workshop and Tutorial Proposal Submission Deadline:** December 9, 2024
*   **Notification of Acceptance (Workshops and Tutorials):** December 16, 2024
*   **Paper Submission Deadline (Technical Papers):** February 6, 2025
*   **HPDC 2025 Achievement Award Nomination Deadline:** February 28, 2025
*   **Poster Submission Deadline:** March 13, 2025
*   **Notification for HPDC 2025 Achievement Award:** March 21, 2025
*   **Notification of Acceptance (Technical Papers):** April 4, 2025
*   **Notification of Acceptance (Posters):** April 7, 2025
*   **Travel Grant Application Deadline:** April 13, 2025
*   **Notification of Awards (Travel Grant):** April 21, 2025
*   **Camera-ready Version (Technical Papers):** May 1, 2025
*   **Hotel Booking Deadline:** June 20, 2025
*   **Late Registration Deadline:** June 23, 2025

## Paper Submission Categories

Submissions to HPDC can be made in one of the following two categories:

1.  **Regular Papers:** The primary focus should be to describe new research ideas supported by experimental implementation and evaluation.
2.  **Open-source Tools and Data Papers:** The primary focus should be to describe the design, development, and evaluation of new open-source tools or novel data sources.

Authors are required to indicate the category of the paper in the title (e.g., "Paper Type: Regular" or "Paper Type: Open-source tools and data paper"). Submissions in both categories will be evaluated to the same standards. The chosen category at the time of submission cannot be changed after the submission deadline.

## ACM Publication

Papers accepted and presented at HPDC 2025 will be published in the ACM Digital Library at no additional cost to the authors.

## Submission Guidelines

*   Authors are invited to submit technical papers of at most **11 pages** in PDF format, excluding references.
*   Accepted papers will have the flexibility to use an additional page in the camera-ready to incorporate feedback from the reviewers.
*   Papers should be formatted in the ACM Proceedings Style (using `sigconf` from [ACM Proceedings Template](https://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template)).
*   Submitted papers must be original work that has not appeared in and is not under consideration for another conference or a journal.

## Anonymizing Submissions

HPDC uses **dual-anonymous reviewing**. Avoid identifying yourself or your institution explicitly or by implication (e.g., through references or acknowledgments).

*   The first page should use the paper ID assigned during registration in place of author names.
*   Reference your past work in the third person, as you would any other piece of related work.
*   If your submission extends a previous workshop paper or relates to a submission under review, cite the other work anonymously and email the deanonymized work to the PC chairs.
*   If your submission reports on experiences with a system at your institution, refer to the system anonymously but describe the properties needed for evaluation.
*   Tool/data papers should also adhere to the double-blind submission policy.

## arXiv Submission Policy

Having an arXiv paper does not prohibit submission to HPDC. arXiv papers are not peer-reviewed and do not count as prior work. Authors are encouraged to use preventive measures to reduce the chances of accidental breach of anonymity (e.g., use a different title in the submission and do not upload/revise the arXiv version during the review period).

## Author List After Acceptance

The author list cannot be changed after acceptance.

## Conflict of Interest Declaration

At the time of submission, all authors must indicate their conflict of interest with PC members (institutional, collaborative, or personal).

## HPDC Policy on the use of AI

*   HPDC permits the use of AI tools (e.g., ChatGPT, Grammarly) for language rectification. Authors are responsible for the accuracy of the content.
*   AI tools are not eligible for authorship.
*   The use of any AI-generated text must be disclosed in the acknowledgments section, citing the AI system used. The acknowledgment section must still follow dual-anonymous submission guidelines.

## ACM Policy on Authorship

Refer to the [ACM Policy on Authorship](https://www.acm.org/publications/policies/frequently-asked-questions) for all other guidelines, including policies on the use of generative AI tools.

## Contact PC Chairs

*   Ivona Brandić (ivona.brandic@tuwien.ac.at)
*   Robert Wisniewski (bobww123@gmail.com)

## Submissions

Click the button below to access the submission site:

[HPDC Submission Site](https://hpdc.sci.utah.edu/submission)

## Suggestions for Document Preparation for Authors

HPDC authors are encouraged to structure their introduction section as follows:

*   **Motivation:** State the objective and provide quantitative support.
*   **Limitation of state-of-art approaches:** Review prior works and articulate limitations.
*   **Key insights and contributions:** Specify novelty and contributions.
*   **Experimental methodology and artifact availability:** Specify infrastructure and methodology, indicate artifact availability.
*   **Limitations of the proposed approach:** Articulate limitations and conclusions sensitive to assumptions.

This format is a suggestion and not a requirement.

## Ethical Considerations

If your research describes a new security-related attack, please consider adding information about responsible disclosure. The paper should follow ethical principles and not alter security/privacy/equality expectations of users.

## Inclusive Description of Research Contributions

Consider using gender-neutral pronouns, diverse examples, engaging users from diverse backgrounds, and making the paper accessible to visually impaired or color-blind readers.

# Call for Papers

IntelliSys 2025 focuses on intelligent systems and artificial intelligence and how they apply to the real world. IntelliSys provides a leading international forum that brings together researchers and practitioners from diverse fields with the purpose of exploring the fundamental roles, interactions, as well as practical impacts of Artificial Intelligence. It is part of the conference series started in 2013. The conference highlights groundbreaking advancements in generative AI, LLMs, and machine learning. The program will include paper presentations, poster sessions, and project demonstrations, along with prominent keynote speakers and industrial workshops. All submitted papers will be reviewed by experts in the field based on the criteria of originality, significance, quality, and clarity.

## Submission Rounds

### Round 1

## Submission Process

Authors are invited to submit their fully formatted papers, complete with results, tables, figures, and references. All paper submissions will be double-blind peer reviewed and evaluated based on originality, research content, correctness, relevance to conference theme, and readability. Please review the full call for papers guidelines before submitting.

*   **Online Submission:** Paper Submission can be completed online at [www.SAIConference.com/IntelliSys/Submit](www.SAIConference.com/IntelliSys/Submit)
*   **Email Submission:** If you experience difficulties with the online system, you may submit via email to [IntelliSys@SAIConference.com](mailto:IntelliSys@SAIConference.com) ensuring all required details are included.

## Submission Guidelines

*   Accepted formats: `.docx`, `.doc`, `.pdf`, or LaTeX PDF.
*   To comply with the double-blind peer review process, please refrain from including author details, university, country information, or any other author-related information in the paper.
*   Prior to submission, authors are responsible for ensuring their papers are thoroughly checked and proofread. Once submitted, no revisions are permitted during the review process. If accepted, the authors may make minor revisions before final publication to address any identified areas for improvement.
*   At the time of camera-ready submission, please include complete author information as per the paper format.
*   Submissions should be primarily original work. No more than 25% of the text can be drawn from previously published material by the same authors, and any such reuse must be properly cited. Therefore, at least 75% of the manuscript must consist of new, unpublished content.

## Formatting Guidelines

*   Manuscripts should generally be limited to **18 pages** for the main text (excluding references and appendices). Submissions exceeding this limit may be considered at the chair's discretion, particularly for review or survey articles.
*   Manuscripts must present original work and fall within the scope of the conference topics.
*   It is the authors' responsibility to ensure the accuracy of all quotations, citations, figures, maps, and tables within their manuscript.
*   Figures and tables must be positioned within the manuscript where they are discussed and should be clear and easily readable.
*   The manuscript must adhere to the provided template.

## Review Process

Submissions will be reviewed anonymously (double-blind). Therefore, your manuscript must not reveal your identity or affiliation. Specifically: omit author names and affiliations from the manuscript; anonymize citations and mentions of your own prior work that is closely related to the submitted paper; and exclude funding or other acknowledgments.

Each paper will undergo review by at least three regular program committee members or two senior program committee members. Acceptance will be based on:

*   **Novelty:** The paper should explore a new idea, project, or issue; offer new insights on existing research; present new research; or provide a novel perspective on existing information.
*   **Engaging:** The presentation should be interactive and engage the readers.
*   **Significant:** The paper should address and discuss key issues related to improving the effectiveness of current techniques, and its content should be easily understood and widely applicable.
*   **Quality:** Claims made in the paper must be substantiated with adequate data, reference relevant existing work, and honestly acknowledge any limitations.
*   **Clear:** The intended outcomes should be easily understood.
*   **Relevant:** The paper's topic must be relevant to at least one of the conference's designated tracks.

# Call For Papers

The 31st IEEE International Symposium on High-Performance Computer Architecture (HPCA) will be held in **Las Vegas, NV** from **March 1st to March 5th, 2025**.

HPCA is a high-impact premier venue for presenting research results on a wide range of computer architecture topics.

## Topics of Interest

*   Processor, memory, and storage systems architecture
*   Instruction-, thread-, and data-level parallelism
*   Interconnection networks and network interface architecture
*   Domain-specific architectures and Accelerators
*   FPGA, CGRA, and Reconfigurable systems
*   Near/In-Memory computing
*   Cloud, Datacenters, cluster/distributed systems
*   Approximate computing
*   Compilers/Languages/Runtimes for novel architectures
*   IoT, Mobile, Edge, and Embedded architectures
*   Effects of circuits or technology on architecture (3D/chiplets/interposer/wafer-scale)
*   Architecture modeling and simulation methodologies
*   Neuromorphic computing
*   Quantum, Superconducting and Emerging technologies impacting computer architectures
*   Reliability/Fault Tolerance, Energy Efficiency and Sustainability of Computer Systems
*   Security/Privacy
*   Evaluation and measurement of real computing systems

*   Papers must be submitted in printable **PDF format**.
*   Text must be in a minimum **10pt font**.
*   Papers must be at most **11 pages**, not including references.
*   Line spacing (leading) must be no less than **12pt**.
*   No page limit for references.
*   References must include all authors (i.e., do not use et al.).

### Templates and Submission Site

*   Download LaTeX Template: [hpca2025-latex-template.zip](https://hpca-conf.org/2025/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/hpca2025-latex-template.zip)
*   Sample Paper: [HPCA_2025_template.pdf](https://hpca-conf.org/2025/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/HPCA_2025_template-2.pdf)
*   Paper Registration/Submission Site: [Upload Abstracts and Papers to HotCRP](http://hpca2025.hotcrp.com/)

## Paper Evaluation Objectives

The committee will make every effort to judge each submitted paper on its own merits. There will be no target acceptance rate. We expect to accept a wide range of papers with appropriate expectations for evaluation – while papers that build on significant past work with strong evaluations are valuable, papers that open new areas with less rigorous evaluation are equally welcome and especially encouraged. We also acknowledge the wide range of evaluation methodologies in HPCA including modeling, simulation, prototyping, experimental implementation, real product evaluation, etc.

## Paper Formatting Details

*   **Page Limit:** 11 pages, not including references.
*   **Paper Size:** US Letter: 8.5in x 11in
*   **Margins:** Top/Bottom: 0.7in / 1in, Left/Right: 0.7in
*   **Body:** 2-column, single spaced
*   **Space Between Columns:** 0.1in
*   **Line Spacing (Leading):** 12pt
*   **Body Font:** 10pt, Times
*   **Abstract Font:** 9pt, Times, Bold
*   **Section Heading Font:** 12pt, Small caps, Roman numbering (I, II, …)
*   **Subsection Heading Font:** 10pt, Italic, Alpha numbering (A, B, …)
*   **Caption Font:** 9pt (minimum)
*   **References:** 8pt, no page limit, list all authors’ names

## Reviewing Process

Reviewing will be **double blind**. Authors must not include any author names on submitted documents except in the space provided on the submission form. Ensure that the metadata included in the PDF does not give away the authors. Refer to prior work in the third person and include a full citation for the work in the bibliography.

## Authorship Guidelines

IEEE guidelines dictate that authorship should be based on a substantial intellectual contribution. All authors must have met specific conditions related to intellectual contribution, drafting/revising the article, and approving the final version.

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors must register all their conflicts on the paper submission site. Conflicts include advisor-advisee relationships, family members, collaborations within the last 4 years, people from the same institution within the last 4 years, funding relationships, and members of the same research center where unpublished work is regularly discussed. 

*Scenarios that do NOT constitute a conflict include: authors of previously-published, closely related work; service collaborations; co-authoring community-wide tools; people working on similar topics; and people under the same umbrella funding award without close collaboration.*

## ArXiv Submissions

Authors may submit their work to HPCA 2025 even if it appears on Arxiv. However, authors are encouraged to reduce the possibility of their name being disclosed to avoid issues with the double-blind review process.

## Concurrent Submissions

Manuscripts must not have been previously published or accepted for publication in a substantially similar form, nor be under review for any other conference or journal during the HPCA 2025 review period, with specific exceptions for workshops without archived proceedings or venues like arXiv.

## Further Information

For questions regarding topic fit, please contact the program chair at [hpca2025@psu.edu](mailto:hpca2025@psu.edu).

# IEEE HOTI 2025: Call for Papers

Welcome to the 32nd iteration of the IEEE Hot Interconnects symposium. HotI’2025 will be held **virtually from August 20 – 22, 2025**.

## Conference Theme

**Interconnect Software: You can't touch it but you need it**

The latest advancements in photonics, chips, parallel paths, and other cutting-edge interconnect technologies are dazzling. However, the picture is incomplete without the system software needed to exploit their full potential. This edition of Hot Interconnects will explore the underlying software ecosystems that empower interconnect fabrics to support a wide array of applications.

## Topics of Interest

*   Systems software for communication
*   Novel and innovative interconnect architectures
*   Accelerator interconnects, e.g. NVLINK, Infinity Fabric
*   Network software/hardware designed for AI/ML workloads
*   Multi-core processor interconnects

*   Advanced chip-to-chip communication technologies
*   Optical interconnects
*   Protocol and interfaces for inter-processor communication
*   Survivability and fault-tolerance of interconnects
*   High-speed packet processing engines and network processors
*   System and storage area network architectures and protocols
*   High-performance host-network interface architectures
*   High-bandwidth and low-latency I/O
*   Pb/s switching and routing technologies
*   Innovative architectures for supporting collective communication
*   Novel communication architectures to support cloud & grid computing
*   Centralized and distributed cloud interconnects
*   Requirements driving high-performance interconnects
*   Traffic characterization for HPC systems and commercial data centers
*   Software-defined networking and software overlay networks

# IAAI-25: Call for Papers

The Thirty-Seventh Annual Conference on Innovative Applications of Artificial Intelligence (IAAI-25) is scheduled to be held from **February 27 to March 1, 2025**, in **Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA**. IAAI-25 is collocated with the AAAI-25 conference.

## Objective

The objective of IAAI-25 is to showcase successful applications and novel uses of AI. The conference will feature technical papers, best practice papers, invited talks, and panel discussions to explore issues, methods, and lessons learned in the development and deployment of AI applications.

## Submission Focus

IAAI-25 focuses on applications rather than purely algorithmic descriptions. Papers should describe real-world deployments, practical realizations, and the impact of AI technology.

## Tracks and Topics

1.  **Deployed Highly Innovative Applications of AI:**
    *   Must describe *deployed* applications with measurable benefits that include an innovative use of AI technology.
    *   Papers will be judged on task description, application description, innovative AI use, measurable application use and payoff, and lessons learned.
    *   Page limit: up to 8 pages + 1 page for references.

2.  **Emerging Applications of AI:**
    *   Discusses efforts to apply AI tools, techniques, or methods to real-world problems in novel ways, bridging the gap between basic AI research and deployed applications.
    *   Focuses on potential application and engineering considerations, with a clear path to deployment.
    *   Papers will be judged on significance, relevance of AI technology, innovation, path to deployment, content, evaluation, technical quality, and clarity.
    *   Page limit: up to 6 pages + 1 page for references.

3.  **Deployed Innovative Tools for Enabling AI Applications:**
    *   Solicits papers describing *deployed* tools for improving applied AI innovation and deployment.
    *   Areas include process organization, data cleaning, modeling, meta-algorithmics, platforms, novel computational models, interaction, and trusted AI tools.
    *   Papers will be judged on the tool's demonstrated quality improvements, cost reduction, productivity, error reduction, and scalability.
    *   Page limit: up to 6 pages + 1 page for references.

4.  **Innovative Inter-disciplinary AI Integration:**
    *   Focuses on the integration of AI components, exploring how orchestrating methods from different AI silos requires adaptation for practical application.
    *   Emphasizes engineering considerations and human-computer interaction.
    *   Requires clear, transparent, and reproducible cases demonstrating the value of innovation in integration.
    *   Page limit: up to 6 pages + 1 page for references.

5.  **AI Incidents and Best Practices (Short Paper Track):**
    *   Encourages papers analyzing factors related to AI incidents and best practices for prevention or mitigation.
    *   Papers will be reviewed based on their analysis of development/deployment processes, AI incident trends, or best practices for safe system deployment.
    *   Page limit: up to 6 pages. Papers of at most two (2) pages may be submitted for poster presentation only.

## Submission Instructions

*   Electronic submissions are required in PDF format, formatted for United States letter (8.5” x 11") paper, using the **AAAI two-column format** (refer to the [AAAI 2025 Author Kit](https://aaai.org/authorkit25/)).
*   Supplementary material (technical appendix, multimedia, code, data) may be submitted alongside papers, but papers should be self-contained.
*   Submissions are **single-blind**, so identifying information should be included.
*   Authors should register on the IAAI-25 [OpenReview submission site](https://openreview.net/group?id=AAAI.org/2025/Innovative_Applications_of_AI).
*   Paper submission site opens: **July 15, 2024**.
*   Paper submission deadline: **September 2, 2024**.
*   Notification of acceptance or rejection: **October 31, 2024**.
*   Author feedback window: **November 18-22, 2024**.
*   Final acceptance or rejection notification: **December 2, 2024**.
*   Camera-ready copy due: **December 19, 2024**.

## Paper Awards

*   **Festo Best use of AI in Industrial Engineering:** Recognizes innovative AI use in automation solutions. Prize: $1000 + $1000 travel support for the top paper; $500 for runner-up.
*   **DSRI AI Incidents and Best Practices Paper Award:** Recognizes outstanding contributions in analyzing AI incidents and showcasing best practices. Prize: $1000 + $1000 travel support sponsored by the Digital Safety Research Institute (DSRI).

# Call for Papers: IC3K 2025

## Scope

The purpose of the IC3K (International Joint Conference on Knowledge Discovery, Knowledge Engineering and Knowledge Management) is to bring together researchers, engineers and practitioners on the areas of Knowledge Discovery, Knowledge Engineering and Knowledge Management. IC3K is composed of three co-located conferences, each specialized in at least one of the aforementioned main knowledge areas.

Although the conference is back to the normal mode (i.e., in-person), speakers are allowed to present remotely if unable to travel to the venue (hybrid support).

## Conference Areas

IC3K is composed of three co-located conferences:

*   **KDIR:** 17th International Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Information Retrieval
*   **KEOD:** 17th International Conference on Knowledge Engineering and Ontology Development
*   **KMIS:** 17th International Conference on Knowledge Management and Information Systems

## Keynote Speakers

*   **Richard Chbeir**, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour (UPPA), France
*   **Henry Prakken**, Utrecht University, Netherlands

## Paper Submission

### General Submission Guidelines

Authors should submit a paper in English, carefully checked for correct grammar and spelling, addressing one or several of the conference areas or topics. Each paper should clearly indicate the nature of its technical/scientific contribution, and the problems, domains or environments to which it is applicable. To facilitate the double-blind paper evaluation method, authors are kindly requested to produce and provide the paper **WITHOUT any reference to any of the authors**, including the authors’ personal details, the acknowledgments section of the paper and any other reference that may disclose the authors’ identity.

Only original papers should be submitted. Authors are advised to read INSTICC's ethical norms regarding plagiarism and self-plagiarism thoroughly before submitting and must make sure that their submissions do not substantially overlap work which has been published elsewhere or simultaneously submitted to a journal or another conference with proceedings. Papers that contain any form of plagiarism will be rejected without reviews.

All papers must be submitted through the online submission platform PRIMORIS and should follow the instructions and templates that can be found under Guidelines and Templates. After the paper submission has been successfully completed, authors will receive an automatic confirmation e-mail.

### Submission Types

*   **Position/Regular Paper:** Representing completed and validated research.
*   **Position Paper:** Portraying a short report of work in progress or an arguable opinion about an issue discussing ideas, facts, situations, methods, procedures or results of scientific research focused on one of the conference topic areas.

## Publications

All accepted papers will be published in the conference proceedings, under an ISBN reference, on paper and on digital support.

# ICAI'25: Call for Papers

The **27th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (ICAI'25)** is an integral part of **The 2025 World Congress in Computer Science, Computer Engineering, & Applied Computing (CSCE'25)**. This significant congress will be held from **July 21-24, 2025**, in **Las Vegas, USA**.

ICAI serves as a vital platform for researchers, scholars, professionals, students, and academicians seeking to foster working relationships and access the latest research results in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning. AI is recognized as a crucial multi-disciplinary field that underpins many challenging problems in computer science. The conference aims to provide a platform for sharing novel ideas and research results on the application of human cognition models in practical computing applications, promoting interdisciplinary discussions on innovations and solutions for human brain processes, learning mechanisms, and decision-making processes.

# Call for Papers

## Scope

The purpose of the International Conference on Agents and Artificial Intelligence (ICAART) is to bring together researchers, engineers, and practitioners interested in the theory and applications in the areas of Agents and Artificial Intelligence, covering both applications and current (advanced) research work. The scientific goal is to stimulate them in developing new ideas for further progress. ICAART focuses on Agents, Multi-Agent Systems, Software Platforms, and Distributed Problem Solving. It also focuses on Artificial Intelligence, Knowledge Representation, Planning, Learning, Scheduling, and Perception. Applications are in both areas, utilizing Natural Language Processing (NLP), Large Language Models (LLMs), Legal Technologies, and Quantum Computing.

Papers describing original work are invited. Accepted papers, presented at the conference by one of the authors, will be published in the Proceedings of ICAART with an ISBN. Acceptance will be based on quality, relevance, and originality. Both full research reports and work-in-progress reports are welcome. There will be both oral and poster sessions.

Special sessions, dedicated to case-studies and commercial presentations, as well as tutorials dedicated to technical/scientific topics are also envisaged.

# Call for Papers - ICAIL 2025

The 20th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Law (ICAIL 2025) will be held in **Chicago at Northwestern University, June 16 to 20, 2025**.

Since 1987, ICAIL has been the foremost international conference addressing research in Artificial Intelligence and Law. It is organized biennially by the **International Association for Artificial Intelligence and Law (IAAIL)**, in cooperation with the ACM-SIGAI and Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI).

We invite submissions of **papers** for regular and special tracks, **technology demonstrations**, and proposals for **workshops and tutorials**.

## Conference Details

*   **Dates:** June 16 - 20, 2025
*   **Location:** Chicago, Northwestern University
*   **Participation Options:** Onsite and Online Options are available (physical presence or virtual participation).

## Topics of Interest

We invite submission of original papers on Artificial Intelligence & Law, covering foundations, methods, tools, systems and applications. Topics may include, but are not limited to:

*   Argument mining on legal texts
*   Classification and automatic summarization of legal text
*   Computational methods for negotiation and contract formation
*   Computer-assisted dispute resolution
*   Computable representations of legal rules and domain specific languages for the law
*   Decision support systems in the legal domain
*   Deep learning on data and text from the legal domain
*   Dialog systems in the legal domain
*   e-discovery and e-disclosure
*   e-government, e-democracy and e-justice
*   Empirical research (quantitative and qualitative analysis) on the use of AI systems in legal practice (for example in law courts, lawmaking, legal education and legislative/normative or adjudicative activities in public administration)
*   Innovative applications in AI and Law
*   Philosophical and legal-theoretical analysis of the significance and implications of methodologies or technical features of AI systems (particularly in applications to Law) with respect to fundamental legal concepts and ethical issues.
*   Systems and methods designed for compliance checking with respect to normative principles, rules and standards (legal or ethical)
*   Methodologies for the technical design in AI systems of compliance with normative principles, rules and standards of trustworthy or responsible AI
*   Explainable AI for the legal domain
*   Formal and computational models of legal reasoning (e.g., argumentation, case-based reasoning), including deontic logics
*   Formal and conceptual modeling of fundamental legal concepts
*   Formal and computational models of evidential reasoning
*   Formal models of norms and norm-governed systems
*   Information extraction from legal databases and texts
*   Information retrieval, question answering, and literature recommendation in the legal domain
*   Intelligent legal tutoring systems
*   Intelligent support systems for forensics
*   Interdisciplinary applications of legal informatics methods and systems
*   Knowledge acquisition techniques for the legal domain, including related applications of natural language processing, argument, and data mining
*   Knowledge representation, knowledge engineering, and ontologies in the legal domain
*   Legal design involving AI techniques
*   Machine learning and data analytics applied to the legal domain
*   Natural language processing of legal text, including law-specific standard NLP tasks (e.g., Named Entity Recognition, Semantic Role Labeling, Translation, etc.)
*   Applications of generative AI systems (LLMs) to the legal domain in connection to machine learning systems or knowledge representation systems
*   Normative reasoning by autonomous agents
*   Open and linked data in the legal domain
*   Smart contracts and application of blockchain in the legal domain
*   Visualization techniques for legal information and data

## Paper Submission Guidelines

*   **Length:** Up to 10 pages including references for long papers; up to 5 pages including references for short papers.
*   **Content Requirements:** All papers must make clear their relation to legal information, reasoning, or processes. There should be a statement about the novel scientific contribution. The relation to prior work must be well-developed. The paper ought to report a full and satisfying discussion of its findings.
    *   Papers on generative AI, machine learning or data mining should include discussions of the data, methodology, results, and analysis in sufficient depth beyond merely reporting metrics.
    *   Submissions focusing on the reproduction, validation, constructive scrutinization, and extension of previously published works, datasets, and benchmarks are strongly encouraged.
    *   Papers proposing formal or computational models should provide examples and/or reproducible simulations.
    *   Papers on applications should describe the motivations, techniques, implementation, and evaluation.
    *   All papers should include some discussion about the relevance to legal theory, practice, use of legal information, or impact on processes.
*   **Reproducibility:** It is highly recommended that code and data be published alongside the papers. Program committee members will be instructed to take data and code sharing into account in their reviews.
*   **Formatting:** Papers must be formatted using the ACM sigconf template (for LaTeX) or the interim template layout.docx (for Word), available at [http://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template](http://www.acm.org/publications/proceedings-template). All papers should be converted to PDF prior to electronic submission.
*   **Submission Platform:** Via conftool platform: [https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/](https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/)
*   **Anonymity (Double-Blind Reviewing):** Papers submitted for review must not include names and affiliations of the authors and must not include an acknowledgments section. Any identifying text in the body of the paper (e.g. citing “our work”) should be removed or rephrased to be non-identifying. These aspects can be added at the camera-ready stage. Prior to submission, authors should register their paper on the conference support system to receive an ID number, which should then replace author names and affiliations in the paper. References should include relevant literature, including previous works of the authors, while preserving anonymity.
*   **Preprints:** Submitted papers may not be published as open access preprints before acceptance notifications have been sent. Papers already published as preprints at the time of submission must be flagged as such and must not reference the preprint in the paper.
*   **Rejection Criteria:** Papers not adhering to the page limitation or the anonymity requirements may be rejected without review.
*   **Questions:** Direct to [icail2025@conftool.net](mailto:icail2025@conftool.net).

## Workshops and Tutorials

*   **Dates:** Monday, June 16th and Friday, June 20th.
*   **Proposal Content:** Title, summary of content, biography of presenter(s). Proposals must contain information for evaluation on importance, quality, and community interest, including:
    *   Topic and goals, significance, and appropriateness for ICAIL 2025.
    *   Intended audience, likely number of participants, and publicity plans.
    *   Organization (format, length).
    *   Organizers’ details (background, complete addresses).
*   **Participant Registration:** All participants, including remote attendees, must be registered for the ICAIL conference.
*   **Proposal Submission Deadline:** December 20th, 2024.
*   **Submission Link:** [Form Access](https://sites.northwestern.edu/icail2025/workshops/)

## Demonstrations

*   A session will be organized for the demonstration of creative, robust, and practical working applications and tools.
*   **For demonstrations not connected to a submitted paper:** Submit a two-page extended abstract for review via the conference support system. Accepted abstracts will be published in the conference proceedings.
*   **For demonstrations connected to a submitted paper:** Send an email to the Program Chair by the demo submission deadline to register interest.

## Doctoral Consortium

*   **Purpose:** To promote idea exchange, provide feedback from leading scholars, mentoring, and career discussion for PhD students in AI & Law.
*   **Eligibility:** Current doctoral student with ideally 8-12 months of work remaining. Sole author submission. Must register for and attend the main conference.
*   **Submission Aspects:** Research question, problem identification, knowledge of domain, preliminary ideas/results, methodology, contribution, differentiation from existing approaches.
*   **Submission Format:** Max 10 pages, English, LNCS format, PDF. Submit jointly with a maximum 3-page CV.
*   **Submission Platform:** [https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/](https://www.conftool.net/icail2025/)
*   **Award:** Best Paper of ICAIL 2025 Doctoral Consortium Award.
*   **Chair:** Réka Markovich, University of Luxembourg.

## Important Dates

*   **Demonstration Submission:** January 28, 2025

*   **Registration Opens:** April 24, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Papers Due:** May 5, 2025
*   **Conference Dates:** June 16-20, 2025

## Organizers

*   **Program Chair:** Juliano Maranhão (University of São Paulo)

# ICAPS 2025: Call for Papers

The International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling (ICAPS) is the premier forum for new research results on the theory and applications of planning and scheduling technology.

The 35th edition of the ICAPS conference series will be held in Melbourne, Victoria (Australia), from **November 9th to 14th, 2025**.

The program committee of ICAPS 2025 invites paper submissions on all aspects of automated planning and scheduling. Contributions are welcome in the following categories:

*   **Theoretical papers:** Broaden or improve analytical tools for planning and scheduling problems and algorithms (e.g., complexity results, expressiveness, new theoretical frameworks).
*   **Algorithmic papers:** Describe novel perspectives and substantial improvements for solving planning and scheduling problems (e.g., new optimizations, specializations of existing algorithms, new propagators).
*   **Modelling papers:** Describe new representations of planning and scheduling problems and their solutions (e.g., new mathematical frameworks, emerging problems, refinements of knowledge representation).
*   **Position papers:** Contribute critiques or bold new perspectives of the field (e.g., meta-analysis of research trends, new challenge problems, historical perspectives).
*   **Tools papers:** Describe systems useful to the planning and scheduling community, built using novel algorithmic and engineering techniques (e.g., integrated planning systems, model checkers, visualization tools).

## Topics of Interest

All submissions to the main technical track must be classified in terms of one or more high-level topics and relevant subject-matter keywords. A list of these is available from the [ICAPS 2025 homepage](/organisation/paper_classification_system).

## Key Dates

The reference timezone for all deadlines is UTC-12.

*   **October 1, 2024:** Submission site opens
*   **October 25, 2024:** Abstracts due
*   **November 1, 2024:** Full papers due (electronic submission, PDF)
*   **November 15, 2024:** Desk reject notification
*   **December 16, 2024:** Phase 1 author notification
*   **January 30 to February 4, 2025:** Author feedback period
*   **February 5 to February 28, 2025:** Discussion phase
*   **March 1, 2025:** Notifications are sent to authors

## Author Guidelines

*   All types of papers can be submitted as either **long** (8 pages AAAI style plus one page of references) or **short** (4 pages plus one page of references).
*   Whether the paper is long or short must be indicated at submission time.
*   Over-length papers will be rejected without review.
*   All papers that satisfy length and formatting requirements will be reviewed against standard criteria such as relevance, originality, significance, clarity, and soundness.
*   Submissions are expected to meet the high standards of publication expected by ICAPS. Please refer to the for further details and reviewing guidelines.
*   The review process has three possible outcomes: (1) acceptance for oral presentation and inclusion in the archival proceedings; (2) acceptance for poster presentation and non-archival extended abstract; (3) rejection.
*   Papers submitted to ICAPS 2025 may not be submitted to other conferences or journals during the ICAPS 2025 review period, nor may they be already under review, accepted, or published in other conferences or journals.
*   Authors making multiple submissions must ensure that each submission has significant, unique content. Papers sharing co-authors and substantial overlap will be rejected.
*   The format of ICAPS 2025 will be **in-person**. At least one author of each accepted paper is expected to register and present their work in person, unless exceptional circumstances prevent this.

## Use of Generative AI

*   Papers that include text generated from an LLM are prohibited unless the produced text is presented as part of the paper’s experimental analysis.
*   This policy DOES NOT prohibit authors from using these technologies for editing or polishing author-written text.
*   No AI system satisfies the criteria for authorship of papers published by AAAI Press (ICAPS’ publisher) and, as such, also cannot be used as a citable source in such papers.
*   Authors assume full responsibility for the content of submitted work, including checking for plagiarism and authenticity of all text.

## Ethical / Societal Impact

Authors are encouraged to include a statement of the potential broader impact of their work, including its ethical aspects and future societal consequences.

## Best Paper Awards and Journal Fast Track

Best non-student and student papers will be awarded. These papers may also receive an invitation to submit an extended version to a top AI journal, such as the Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research (JAIR) or the Artificial Intelligence Journal (AIJ).

## Submission Instructions

*   All submissions will be made electronically via [OpenReview](https://openreview.net/group?id=icaps-conference.org/ICAPS/2025/Conference).
*   Submitted papers must be anonymous for double-blind reviewing.
*   Papers must adhere to the page limits of the relevant submission type (long or short) and follow the author kit instructions for formatting. The author kit can be found [here](/files/icaps2025-author-kit.zip).
*   Authors can submit supplementary material (videos, technical proofs, additional experimental results) in addition to the PDF paper.

Failure to comply with the submission instructions will result in desk rejection.

## Double-blind Requirements

*   Omit names and institutions.
*   Refer to prior work by themselves or others in the third person.
*   Ensure that acknowledgement notices or ethics statements do not include information that may identify them.
*   Authors are not discouraged from posting manuscripts onto Arxiv.org or other similar repositories, but should avoid doing so during the bidding and paper assignment process.

## Program Chairs and Contact

*   Daniel Harabor, Monash University, Australia
*   Miquel Ramirez, University of Melbourne, Australia

For inquiries, please contact: [icaps25pc@googlegroups.com](mailto:icaps25pc@googlegroups.com)

## Important Dates

*   **Paper Submission Deadline:** **16 September 2024** (23:59 PST)
*   **Submission of accompanying videos:** Window 1: **August 5 - September 9, 2024**; Window 2: **September 17 - September 22, 2024** (23:59 PST)

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Submission Platform:** Papers can be submitted on the [PaperPlaza Portal](https://ras.papercept.net/conferences/conferences/ICRA25/program/).
*   **Page Limit:** A maximum of **6 pages** for the paper (including text, figures, tables, and acknowledgements) plus any number of pages for bibliography/references. Papers exceeding the (6+n) page limit will be returned without review.
*   **Format:** All papers must be submitted in **PDF** and must follow the **ICRA double-column format**. Information and templates are available [here](https://2025.ieee-icra.org/contribute/paper-submission-instructions/).
*   **Video Submission:** Strongly encouraged, with the following guidelines:
    *   File size: up to 20MB
    *   Format (only one): mpeg, mp4, mpg
    *   Maximum duration: 180 sec.
    *   Minimum height: 480
    *   Minimum frame rate (fps): 20
    *   Scan type: Progressive
*   **Templates:** [PPT Template Available for Download](https://2025.ieee-icra.org/ICRA_Template_Master.pptx)

## Guidelines Regarding the Use and Disclosure of AI Tools for Authors

*   Generative AI tools and technologies, such as ChatGPT, may not be listed as authors of a paper submitted to ICRA 2025.
*   The use of content generated by AI in an article (including text, figures, images, and code) must be disclosed in the **acknowledgments section**.

# Call for Papers: ICCC'25

The 16th International Conference on Computational Creativity (ICCC’25) will be held in **Campinas, Brazil**, from **June 23rd to June 27th, 2025**. ICCC is the sole scientific conference dedicated to computational creativity, covering all its facets, from theoretical frameworks to practical applications.

Computational creativity is defined as the art, science, philosophy, and engineering of computational systems which, by taking on particular responsibilities, exhibit behaviours that unbiased observers would deem to be creative. The field is thriving with advancements in formalizing machine creativity and exciting applications across sciences, arts, literature, and gaming.

## Themes and Topics

Original research contributions are solicited in all areas related to Computational Creativity research and practice, including but not limited to:

*   **Applications of Computational Creativity:** in music, language, games, visual arts, design, architecture, entertainment, education, mathematical invention, scientific discovery, programming.
*   **Human-Machine Co-Creativity:** systems, studies, frameworks, or methodologies related to co-creativity between humans and AI, emphasizing machine as a creative partner.
*   **Computational Creativity Evaluation:** metrics, frameworks, formalisms, and methodologies for evaluating creativity in computational systems or their societal perception.
*   **Social Models:** computational models of social aspects of creativity, including social creativity, diffusion of ideas, collaboration, team dynamics, and creativity in social settings.
*   **Computational Paradigms:** computational approaches for modelling cognitive aspects of creativity, such as heuristic search, analogical and meta-level reasoning, cognitive architectures, and re-representation.
*   **Interdisciplinary Perspectives:** drawing from philosophy and/or sociology in the context of creative AI systems.
*   **Data and Creativity:** data science approaches, resource development, and data gathering/knowledge curation for creative AI, with a focus on scalable, extensible, and open-source datasets.
*   **Societal Impact:** ethical considerations in the design, deployment, or testing of creative AI systems, and studies on the societal impact of computational creativity and generative AI.
*   **Psychological Factors:** computational models of psychological factors enhancing creativity (emotion, surprise, reflection, motivation, etc.), as well as social or experiential factors related to novelty and originality.
*   **Provocations:** raising new issues that question the foundations of the discipline or shed new light on debates.

A note on generative AI models: While welcomed, applications must be properly situated in the CC literature and evaluated according to field standards.

## Paper Types

We welcome five types of full papers:

*   **Technical papers:** Focus on hypotheses about creative behaviour in computational systems, requiring solid experimentation, models, proof, or argumentation, with strong evaluation.
*   **System or Resource description papers:** Describe the building and deployment of a creative system or resource, emphasizing engineering achievement, technical challenges, reusable resources, and some evaluation.
*   **Study papers:** Draw on allied fields (psychology, philosophy, etc.) or appeal to broader AI/CS areas, providing novel perspectives on CC systems or their evaluation.
*   **Cultural application papers:** Present the use of creative software in a cultural setting (art exhibitions, concerts, literature, games, etc.), detailing the system's role, results, and feedback.
*   **Position papers:** Present opinions on CC research, future directions, speculative explorations, or current issues, requiring careful argumentation and thorough knowledge of the field.

## Important Dates

All deadlines are 23:59 anywhere on Earth time.

*   **Abstracts due:** February 21, 2025
*   **Submissions due (Full Papers):** February 28, 2025

*   **Conference:** June 23–27, 2025

## Submission Instructions

Submissions are a two-stage process:

1.  **Initial Submission:** Title and abstract (100–200 words). Submit via EasyChair: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=iccc202501](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=iccc202501)
2.  **Full Paper Submission:** Update the EasyChair abstract with your manuscript file.

*   **Page Limit:** 8 pages + up to 2 pages for references.
*   **Anonymity:** Papers must be anonymous for double-blind review. Remove institutional references and refer to past work in the third person.
*   **Formatting:** PDF document formatted according to ICCC style. Templates available:
    *   [LaTeX Template](https://computationalcreativity.net/ICCC-author-kit-2022.zip)
    *   [Word Template](https://computationalcreativity.net/ICCC-author-kit-Word.zip)
*   **Presentation:** Accepted papers must be presented at the conference by an author, requiring registration and live participation. Full papers require a 15-minute talk plus 10 minutes for Q&A; short papers require an 8-minute talk plus Q&A.
*   **Double Submissions:** Work submitted must not be under review elsewhere.

# Call for Papers: ICCBR 2025

Welcome to the **33rd International Conference on Case-Based Reasoning (ICCBR) 2025**, taking place in **Biarritz, France**, from **June 30th to July 3rd, 2025**.

ICCBR is the premier annual meeting of the CBR community and the leading international conference on this topic. Researchers from around the globe will present the latest results of their work and discuss future directions for the field.

## Theme: Generative AI and CBR

"**Generative AI and CBR**" is this year’s conference theme, directing the community’s attention to the explosion of Generative AI permeating and changing all aspects of work, life, and societies. This year, we focus on the question: “What are some roles CBR can play to address some of the challenges stemming from Generative AI’s growing pervasion in our society?”

We look forward to receiving papers around this theme, whether position papers or roadmapping proposals, as well as traditional basic or applied research papers. We also welcome all research papers centered on core CBR, whether theoretical, applied, or fielded.
